case_metadata.title: Case 9452: Toxic Condition with Unknown History Leading to Death

source.journal: Not specified in the text, likely a medical case discussion transcript
source.pages: Pages are not explicitly numbered but can be inferred within the provided text.

social_history.other: No known relevant social history mentioned

surgical_history.pregnancies_wife: Wife had two pregnancies ending in miscarriages (P.H. Not given, except that his wife's only two pregnancies had ended in miscarriages.)

Nurse A.role: Provides initial patient care (inferred from 'Orders' section)

turn_1.speaker: Nurse A
turn_1.timestamp: June 25, 1923, Upon arrival at Emergency Ward
turn_1.message: Sir, can you tell us what brought you in today? We need to get some information.
turn_1.intention: Initial patient assessment and information gathering upon arrival.
turn_1.context: Patient is entering through the Emergency Ward in a toxic condition and cannot initially provide history.
turn_1.source_reference: Case 9452: An American agent of forty entered through the Emergency Ward June 25, 1923, in so toxic a condition that he could give no history.

turn_2.speaker: Caregiver
turn_2.timestamp: June 26, 1923, The next day after admission
turn_2.message: Hello, I am his wife. He hasn't been feeling well for months.  For the past four months he's looked so worried and lost weight. About a week ago, he started complaining about chest pain.
turn_2.intention: Provide patient history as patient was initially unable to.
turn_2.context: Wife providing history the day after admission as patient was too ill upon arrival.
turn_2.source_reference: Case 9452: The following history was obtained the next day from his wife. For four months the patient had looked worried and emaciated. June 19 he complained of pain in the right lower chest caused he said by an injury to the chest.

turn_3.speaker: Caregiver
turn_3.message: He said it was an injury to his chest. He's been breathing so fast, with these grunting noises when he breathes out. He looks terribly sick, but he wouldn't say he felt bad.  He even went to work the day after the pain started but came right back home. He was blue and shivering, but still wouldn't rest!
turn_3.intention: Describe acute symptom onset and patient's behavior.
turn_3.context: Continuing to describe the progression of the illness over the past week.
turn_3.source_reference: Case 9452: He breathed rapidly, with grunting expirations, and looked very ill, though he did not complain of malaise. The following day he went to work, but was very soon forced to go home. He looked extremely ill, blue and cold, but would not go to bed.

turn_4.speaker: Caregiver
turn_4.message: For four days he just walked around the house, still breathing fast and grunting. He had chest pain, I think he had a fever, but we didn't take his temperature. He said his head hurt a little, he was very thirsty, and just felt unwell, but no cough.
turn_4.intention: Detail symptoms experienced at home before seeking medical help.
turn_4.context: Further describing the progression of symptoms at home.
turn_4.source_reference: Case 9452: For the four following days he remained at home, walking about the house, with rapid grunting respirations. He had pain in the right lower chest, apparently high fever,—though his temperature was not taken,—slight headache, severe thirst, and moderate malaise, but no cough or sputum.

turn_5.speaker: Caregiver
turn_5.timestamp: June 26, 1923, Describing worsening condition and arm swellings
turn_5.message: Sunday night, June 23rd, he got so weak he finally went to bed. A doctor came and strapped his chest. Yesterday morning, his temperature was 104! Last night, I noticed these tender swellings on both his forearms.
turn_5.intention: Describe the events leading to seeking medical attention and new symptoms.
turn_5.context: Describing the acute worsening and new symptom of arm swellings.
turn_5.source_reference: Case 9452: The night of June 23 he became so weak that he was forced to go to bed. A physician strapped the right chest. The temperature the next morning was 104°. That night, June 24, bilateral tender swellings were noticed on the forearms.

turn_6.speaker: Caregiver
turn_6.message: For the last couple of days his temperature has been really high, over 103. He’s been confused sometimes, but otherwise, he's been about the same. He's been drinking a lot of fluids.
turn_6.intention: Summarize the patient's condition just before hospital admission.
turn_6.source_reference: Case 9452: During the next two days the temperature was over 103° on several observations, and the patient had been mentally confused but otherwise in apparently the same condition. During the past week he had taken much fluid.

turn_7.speaker: Dr. Cabot
turn_7.timestamp: June 26, 1923, Morning discussion based on history and initial exam
turn_7.message: So, we have a 'walking pneumonia' case here, wouldn't give himself a chance.  The physical exam should tell us more about these arm swellings. No idea what they are yet.
turn_7.intention: Initial assessment and highlighting key features of the case for discussion.
turn_7.context: Beginning of clinical discussion after initial history and examination.
turn_7.source_reference: Case 9452: We used to hear a great deal about 'walking typhoid.' Here is obviously a 'walking pneumonia' in a man who would not give himself any sort of show. Isuppose the physical examination will tell us more about the swellings on -the arms. I have no idea what they are.

turn_8.speaker: Dr. Cabot
turn_8.message: Pneumonia is the most obvious diagnosis, unless the physical exam reveals something else.  Lung signs suggest pneumonia, possibly with fluid.  These forearm areas are puzzling, though.  Haven't seen exactly this before.
turn_8.intention: Suggest pneumonia as primary diagnosis and express uncertainty about arm lesions.
turn_8.context: Discussing initial differential diagnoses based on presented information.
turn_8.source_reference: Case 9452: One would naturally say that this is pneumonia, unless something more turns up in the physical examination. Vocal fremitus ought not to be diminished. Nevertheless from the lung signs this can perfectly well be a pneumonia, with very possibly some fluid in the chest. I do not know what these areas on the forearms are. I do not remember having seen exactly that thing.

turn_9.speaker: Dr. Cabot
turn_9.timestamp: June 26, 1923, Considering other possibilities for arm swellings
turn_9.message: During the influenza epidemic, we saw similar swellings in legs, above the knee, and sometimes in the rectus muscle. Maybe part of the same septic process in his lungs.  But this location...  The only other thing I've seen like this is glanders, but that seems unlikely.
turn_9.intention: Broaden differential to include septic processes and less likely diagnoses like glanders.
turn_9.context: Exploring potential causes for the unusual forearm swellings.
turn_9.source_reference: Case 9452: We saw swellings like that in the legs above the knee during the influenza epidemic, and sometimes also in the rectus muscle. Isuppose it is part of the same septic process that he has in his lung, but I do not remember having seen it in this position. The only thing other than a septic process that I have ever seen in this position is glanders.

turn_10.speaker: Dr. Cabot
turn_10.message: Glanders is unlikely. He'd likely have more 'farcy-buds'. And we have no history of horse contact, and glanders would be more chronic, less lung-focused at first.
turn_10.intention: Justify ruling out glanders based on clinical and epidemiological grounds.
turn_10.context: Continuing to refine the differential diagnosis and exclude less probable conditions.
turn_10.source_reference: Case 9452: I do not believe it is glanders. He would have more 'farcy-buds.' We have no reason to suppose that he is in touch with horses or that he would have so much in his lungs and so little elsewhere if he had glanders, a chronic disease. So I should rule it out.

turn_11.speaker: Dr. Cabot
turn_11.message: Leukocyte count is low.  Blood condition is likely from the lung process, not the arms directly.
turn_11.intention: Interpret blood work in the context of pneumonia, not primary arm infection.
turn_11.context: Analyzing lab results to understand the underlying pathology.
turn_11.source_reference: Case 9452: The leucocytes are notably low. The blood condition is all due, presumably, to the process he has in his lungs and not to his forearms.

turn_12.speaker: Dr. Cabot
turn_12.timestamp: June 26, 1923, Summarizing initial diagnosis and concerns
turn_12.message: So, pneumonia, possibly with empyema, and sepsis foci in the forearm. These foci make me wonder about acute endocarditis with pneumonia, though emboli are unusual in pneumonic endocarditis.  Still, leaning against endocarditis.  Otherwise, no other organ involvement suspected.
turn_12.intention: Synthesize initial clinical impression and refine differential diagnosis.
turn_12.context: Formulating a preliminary clinical diagnosis and considering potential complications.
turn_12.source_reference: Case 9452: I think he died of pneumonia with very possibly empyema and foci of sepsis in the forearm. These foei of sepsis make us wonder whether this is one of the not at all rare cases with acute endocarditis associated with pneumonia, though in the cases I have seen there have not been embolie symptoms. I have not seen emboli coming from a pneumonic endocarditis. So on the whole my impression is against acute endocarditis as a source of these lesions on the forearm. Aside from his pneumonia I do not see any evidence of disease. I do not see any reason to suspect his kidneys or his heart or any other organ.

turn_13.speaker: Dr. Young
turn_13.message: Do you think this is a pneumococcus process?
turn_13.intention: Inquire about the likely causative organism of the pneumonia.
turn_13.context: Focusing on identifying the specific pathogen.
turn_13.source_reference: Case 9452: Dr. Young : Do you think it is a pneumococcus process?

turn_14.speaker: Dr. Cabot
turn_14.timestamp: June 26, 1923, Considering Staphylococcus based on urine culture
turn_14.message: Staphylococcus in the urine and forearm lesions makes me think of something else.  'Profuse growth' is significant, isn't it?
turn_14.intention: Suggest staphylococcus infection based on urine culture and clinical findings.
turn_14.context: Shifting towards staphylococcus as a more probable etiology.
turn_14.source_reference: Case 9452: Dr. Cabot : The finding of the staphylococcus in the urine and the lesions on the forearm would incline us to think of something else. Dr. Young: Don't you think a 'profuse growth' is important?

turn_15.speaker: Dr. Young
turn_15.timestamp: June 26, 1923, Supporting Staphylococcus as a possibility
turn_15.message: Urinary cultures, I admit we don't know much about them, but it's known that in staph infections, the same organism can appear in urine and lesions.
turn_15.intention: Provide evidence supporting staphylococcus as a systemic infection affecting multiple sites.
turn_15.context: Reinforcing the possibility of staphylococcal etiology with microbiological correlation.
turn_15.source_reference: Case 9452: Dr. Young : I don't think there is enough known about them. But it is definitely known that in staphylococcus infections apparently the same organism can be obtained from the urine as from the lesions.

turn_16.speaker: Dr. Cabot
turn_16.message: We should also consider tuberculosis. Signs are mostly unilateral, not apical, and death was quick unless it's miliary TB. Dr. Young's staph idea is good though.
turn_16.intention: Include tuberculosis in the differential, but acknowledge staphylococcus as a strong possibility.
turn_16.context: Expanding the differential again but prioritizing the staphylococcus suggestion.
turn_16.source_reference: Case 9452: Dr. Cabot: In a case like this we ought to consider the possibility of tuberculosis. The signs are almost wholly unilateral; they are not at the apices; and he died too soon unless it is of the miliary type. I think Dr. Young's suggestion is a good one.

turn_17.speaker: Physician A
turn_17.message: Could this fit influenza pneumonia better?
turn_17.intention: Propose influenza pneumonia as another diagnostic possibility.
turn_17.source_reference: Case 9452: A Physician : Wouldn't you think it would conform more to the type of influenza pneumonia ?

turn_18.speaker: Dr. Cabot
turn_18.message: No, I don't think so. Influenza pneumonia usually has more bleeding - nosebleeds, bloody sputum, blood in trachea and lungs post-mortem. Nothing mentioned here about that.
turn_18.intention: Refute influenza pneumonia diagnosis based on typical presentation.
turn_18.context: Comparing the case to typical influenza pneumonia presentation.
turn_18.source_reference: Case 9452: Dr. Cabot: No, I should not. I don't think we have a very clean cut picture of influenza pneumonia, but the thing that has struck me in it is the amount of blood everywhere, nose bleed, bloody sputum, blood in the trachea and in the lungs post mortem. Nothing is said about that here.

turn_19.speaker: Physician B
turn_19.timestamp: June 26, 1923, Questioning low white blood cell count
turn_19.message: Is the low white count because of low resistance?
turn_19.intention: Seek explanation for low leukocyte count in pneumonia context.
turn_19.context: Discussing the prognostic significance of the low white blood cell count.
turn_19.source_reference: Case 9452: A Physician: Is his low white count on account of his low resistance?

turn_20.speaker: Dr. Cabot
turn_20.timestamp: June 26, 1923, Explaining low white blood cell count significance
turn_20.message: Yes. Low white count in pneumonia is bad news, poor prognosis, but doesn't rule out pneumonia itself.
turn_20.intention: Confirm the negative prognostic implication of low white blood cell count.
turn_20.context: Explaining the clinical significance of the low white blood cell count.
turn_20.source_reference: Case 9452: Dr. Cabot : Yes. We always hate to see a low white count in pneumonia. It is a bad prognosis, but does not in any way exclude pneumonia.

turn_21.speaker: Dr. Richardson
turn_21.timestamp: Post-mortem examination, June 27, 1923, Describing forearm cellulitis
turn_21.message: The forearms showed cellulitis, as you suspected, Dr. Cabot.
turn_21.intention: Confirm clinical finding of cellulitis in the forearms during autopsy.
turn_21.context: Reporting anatomical findings after post-mortem examination.
turn_21.source_reference: Case 9452: Dr. Richardson: The forearm showed the condition that Dr. Cabot has spoken about,— cellulitis.

turn_22.speaker: Dr. Richardson
turn_22.timestamp: Post-mortem examination, June 27, 1923, Describing pleural findings
turn_22.message: No fluid in the peritoneal cavity. Appendix, esophagus, GI tract unremarkable.  Intestines had some reddening, common in sepsis. We sometimes see hemorrhages, even necrosis, in sepsis cases. In one staph infection case, I remember intestinal abscesses, like in lungs.
turn_22.intention: Describe findings in peritoneal cavity and GI tract, noting sepsis-related changes in intestines.
turn_22.context: Continuing to report anatomical findings, focusing on abdominal organs.
turn_22.source_reference: Case 9452: There was no fluid in the peritoneal cavity. The appendix was negative. The esophagus and gastro-intestinal tract showed nothing for record. The intestines are mentioned as showing some areas of reddening. In these sepsis cases not infrequently we find hemorrhagicareas in the mucosa of the stomach and intes tine, and they may go on from simple areas of hemorrhage to areas of necrosis. In one case of staphylococcus infection which I remember very well there were small abscesses in the mucosa of the intestine the same as in the lungs or anywhere else.

turn_23.speaker: Dr. Richardson
turn_23.timestamp: Post-mortem examination, June 27, 1923, Describing pleural and lung findings
turn_23.message: Purulent fluid in pleura: 30cc right, 15cc left. Purulent pleuritis. Lungs, not lobar pneumonia, but scattered abscesses throughout.
turn_23.intention: Describe pleural effusion and lung pathology found during autopsy.
turn_23.context: Reporting findings specifically related to the respiratory system.
turn_23.source_reference: Case 9452: Thirty c.c. of thin purulent fluid was found in the right, and fifteen c.c. in the left pleural cavity,—that is, a purulent pleuritis. The lungs showed no definite pneumonia, that is lobar pneumonia; but showed scattered through them smaller and larger areas that were frank enough abscesses.

turn_24.speaker: Dr. Richardson
turn_24.timestamp: Post-mortem examination, June 27, 1923, Describing pericardial and cardiac findings
turn_24.message: Pericardium had purulent fluid, reddening, fibrinous roughening – acute pericarditis. Heart normal weight, valves, cavities negative. Aorta, pulmonary artery, portal veins normal.
turn_24.intention: Detail pericardial inflammation and normal cardiac structures.
turn_24.context: Reporting findings regarding the heart and pericardium.
turn_24.source_reference: Case 9452: In the pericardium we found purulent fluid material, with reddening and fibrinous roughening of the surfaces of the pericardium,—acute pericarditis. The heart weighed 280 grams, the valves and cavities frankly negative. The aorta and great branches, the pulmonary artery, portal veins and radicles out of the picture.

turn_25.speaker: Dr. Richardson
turn_25.timestamp: Post-mortem examination, June 27, 1923, Describing liver, biliary, pancreas, spleen, and kidney findings
turn_25.message: Liver, gallbladder, bile ducts, pancreas, duct of Wirsung, all negative. Spleen small, soft, unusual in sepsis. Kidneys negative macro and micro. Bladder had hemorrhagic cystitis patch near trigonum, likely source of urine blood. Prostate, seminal vesicles, testes negative.
turn_25.intention: Describe findings in liver, biliary system, pancreas, spleen, kidneys, and genitourinary system.
turn_25.context: Completing the report of anatomical findings in various organ systems.
turn_25.source_reference: Case 9452: There was nothing in the liver or gall-bladder; the bile-ducts and pancreas were negative and the duct of Wirsung free. We usually find enlarged soft spleens in sepsis. In this case the spleen was small and a little soft. The kidneys weighed 300 grams and were frankly negative macroscopically and microscopically. In the bladder just above the trigonum there was a definite patch of hemorrhagic cystitis, and Ipresume that was the source of the blood in the urine. The prostate, seminal vesicles and testes were negative.

turn_26.speaker: Dr. Cabot
turn_26.timestamp: Post-mortem examination discussion, June 27, 1923, Questioning kidney abscesses
turn_26.intention: Specifically inquire about kidney abscesses given sepsis context.
turn_26.source_reference: Case 9452: Dr. Cabot : Were there any abscesses in the kidneys ?

turn_27.speaker: Dr. Richardson
turn_27.timestamp: Post-mortem examination discussion, June 27, 1923, Answering kidney abscess question and confirming blood culture
turn_27.message: No, no kidney abscesses.  We got profuse staph growth from heart blood.
turn_27.intention: Confirm absence of kidney abscesses and report positive blood culture for staphylococcus.
turn_27.context: Providing definitive answers and key findings from post-mortem and lab.
turn_27.source_reference: Case 9452: Dr. Richardson : No. We obtained a profuse growth of the staphylococcus from the heart blood.

turn_28.speaker: Dr. Cabot
turn_28.timestamp: Post-mortem examination discussion, June 27, 1923, Questioning source of infection
turn_28.intention: Initiate discussion about the primary source of the staphylococcal sepsis.
turn_28.context: Moving towards determining the origin of the infection.
turn_28.source_reference: Case 9452: Dr. Cabot : Would you hazard a guess as to where the process entered or started?

turn_29.speaker: Dr. Richardson
turn_29.timestamp: Post-mortem examination discussion, June 27, 1923, Suggesting arms as primary source
turn_29.message: Hard to say. Arms first, maybe? Or GU tract?  He had cystitis.  But arms seem more likely.
turn_29.intention: Propose arms as the primary entry point, but consider GU tract as alternative.
turn_29.context: Offering a hypothesis about the infection's origin.
turn_29.source_reference: Case 9452: Dr. Richardson : I always do, and I think you take the other one. It is quite difficult in this case to know whether to think of his arms first, or whether to think, as some do, that these processes come by the genitourinary tract or by other roads. He has a cystitis. I think on the whole his arms came first.

turn_30.speaker: Dr. Cabot
turn_30.timestamp: Post-mortem examination discussion, June 27, 1923, Considering lungs as secondary
turn_30.intention: Confirm the secondary nature of lung involvement.
turn_30.context: Seeking confirmation about the progression of the infection.
turn_30.source_reference: Case 9452: Dr. Cabot : The lungs certainly were secondary?

turn_31.speaker: Dr. Richardson
turn_31.timestamp: Post-mortem examination discussion, June 27, 1923, Confirming secondary lung involvement
turn_31.message: Yes, looks like it.  Everything inside looks secondary.
turn_31.intention: Agree with the secondary nature of internal organ involvement.
turn_31.context: Confirming the sequential progression of the infection.
turn_31.source_reference: Case 9452: Dr. Richardson : One would think so. The whole thing inside looks secondary.

turn_32.speaker: Dr. Cabot
turn_32.timestamp: Post-mortem examination discussion, June 27, 1923, Noting patient's lack of complaint about arms
turn_32.message: Interesting he didn't mention his arms.  Complained of chest.
turn_32.intention: Highlight discrepancy between patient's complaint and suspected primary infection site.
turn_32.context: Pointing out clinical inconsistencies in the case.
turn_32.source_reference: Case 9452: Dr. Cabot: It is interesting that apparently he did not say a word about his arms. He was complaining about his chest.

turn_33.speaker: Dr. Richardson
turn_33.timestamp: Post-mortem examination discussion, June 27, 1923, Acknowledging deep cellulitis in arms
turn_33.message: True, against arms as start is the deep cellulitis.
turn_33.intention: Acknowledge a point against the arms being the primary infection site.
turn_33.context: Considering counterarguments to the arm-origin hypothesis.
turn_33.source_reference: Case 9452: Dr. Richardson : Against the arms as a starting point, of course, is the fact that the cellulitis seemed to be deeply seated.

turn_34.speaker: Dr. Young
turn_34.timestamp: Post-mortem examination discussion, June 27, 1923, Dismissing bladder as primary source
turn_34.message: Bladder starting point is unlikely.  Absorption from bladder is minimal.
turn_34.intention: Dismiss genitourinary tract as primary infection source.
turn_34.context: Further narrowing down the potential origin of the infection.
turn_34.source_reference: Case 9452: Dr: Young : I do not believe it started in the bladder. I think the absorption from the urinary bladder is very slight.

turn_35.speaker: Dr. Cabot
turn_35.timestamp: Post-mortem examination discussion, June 27, 1923, Considering skin/subcutaneous tissue as common entry
turn_35.message: Skin or subcutaneous tissue is often the entry point for this organism, right?
turn_35.intention: Reiterate skin/subcutaneous tissue as a common portal of entry for staphylococcus.
turn_35.context: Returning to the skin as a likely primary source.
turn_35.source_reference: Case 9452: Dr. Cabot : In general this organism starts in the skin or subcutaneous tissue as often as anywhere ?

turn_36.speaker: Dr. Richardson
turn_36.timestamp: Post-mortem examination discussion, June 27, 1923, Confirming skin/subcutaneous tissue as common entry
turn_36.intention: Confirm skin/subcutaneous tissue as common entry point.
turn_36.context: Agreement on common portal of entry.

turn_37.speaker: Physician B
turn_37.timestamp: Post-mortem examination discussion, June 27, 1923, Noting delay in arm symptom onset
turn_37.message: Arm symptoms only mentioned five days after lung symptoms.
turn_37.intention: Point out the temporal discrepancy between lung and arm symptoms.
turn_37.context: Highlighting the delayed onset of arm symptoms relative to pulmonary symptoms.
turn_37.source_reference: Case 9452: A Physician : The symptoms in his arms are not referred to until five days after his pulmonary symptoms.

turn_38.speaker: Dr. Cabot
turn_38.timestamp: Post-mortem examination discussion, June 27, 1923, Acknowledging delayed arm symptoms as a concern
turn_38.intention: Express concern about the delayed onset of arm symptoms.
turn_38.context: Acknowledging the clinical puzzle of symptom timing.
turn_38.source_reference: Case 9452: Dr. Cabot: Yes, that sticks in my crop a good deal.

turn_39.speaker: Dr. Cabot
turn_39.timestamp: Post-mortem examination discussion, June 27, 1923, Reflecting on urine culture follow-up
turn_39.message: Should we have pushed the urine culture more? Should we have diagnosed staph sepsis earlier?
turn_39.intention: Reflect on potential missed diagnostic opportunities.
turn_39.source_reference: Case 9452: Therapeutically we do not know anything to do for these things. People recover from slighter degrees of staphylococcus sepsis, boils, carbuncles, which represent this infection in slighter form. The point that chiefly interests me is whether we ought to have followed up our urine cultures harder, so that we ought to have said at once, this is staphylococcus sepsis.

turn_40.speaker: Dr. Young
turn_40.timestamp: Post-mortem examination discussion, June 27, 1923, Supporting urine culture follow-up
turn_40.message: Yes, there's enough to suggest we should follow it up. Staph does appear in urine in some cases.  Value of that, I'm not sure.
turn_40.intention: Agree on the importance of urine culture follow-up, but uncertain about its definitive value.
turn_40.context: Reinforcing the idea of improving diagnostic protocols based on this case.
turn_40.source_reference: Case 9452: Dr. Young: I think there is enough in it so that we should follow it up. Apparently the staphylococcus does come through in a fair proportion of cases at least, if not in a large pro- portion. Whether that would be of value I don't know.

turn_41.speaker: Physician B
turn_41.timestamp: Post-mortem examination discussion, June 27, 1923, Questioning staph septicemia recovery rates
turn_41.message: How often do staph septicemia cases recover?
turn_41.intention: Seek information on prognosis of staphylococcal septicemia.
turn_41.context: Discussing the clinical course and outcome of staphylococcal septicemia.
turn_41.source_reference: Case 9452: A Physician : Can you tell me how often cases of staphylococcus septicemia recover?

turn_42.speaker: Dr. Cabot
turn_42.timestamp: Post-mortem examination discussion, June 27, 1923, Discussing staph infections vs. septicemia and recovery
turn_42.message: Not sure about septicemia specifically, but staph infections generally, like carbuncles, many recover. Kidney staph infections also often recover, even without surgery.  'Septicemia' proven by blood culture during life – those, I've never seen survive.
turn_42.intention: Differentiate between localized staph infections and septicemia regarding prognosis.
turn_42.context: Clarifying the spectrum of staphylococcal infections and their outcomes.
turn_42.source_reference: Case 9452: Dr. Cabot : No. I was not speaking just now of staphylococcus septicemias but of staphylococcus infections of the body. I should suppose that almost all carbuncles are staphylococcus. Of : course we know that many of them recover. My guess is that there are a good many staphylococcus processes in the kidney with recovery. ' Dr. Cabot : And often without operation. Whether we should call that septicemia or not I don't know. In the carbuncle, for instance, I think it is in the blood before it is in the neck. So Isuppose with the kidney, it is always started in the blood. But if a septicemia is meant which is proved during life by a culture, I never knew a case that lived.

turn_43.speaker: House Officer A
turn_43.timestamp: Post-mortem examination discussion, June 27, 1923, Sharing anecdotal case of staph septicemia
turn_43.message: We had a case recently - neck abscess, then pneumonia, foot abscess, staph in blood, four times.
turn_43.intention: Share a similar case anecdote to illustrate staphylococcal septicemia presentation.
turn_43.context: Providing a real-world example to the discussion.
turn_43.source_reference: Case 9452: A House Officer: We had a case a few weeks ago in the wards where we recovered the staphylococcus from the blood. It started with an abscess in his neck; he developed a pneumonia and an abscess in his foot, and we recovered the staphylococcus from his blood about four times.

turn_44.speaker: Dr. Cabot
turn_44.timestamp: Post-mortem examination discussion, June 27, 1923, Comparing anecdotal case to current case
turn_44.message: Like this case - lung then skin infection. Yellow staph?
turn_44.intention: Compare the anecdotal case to the current case and inquire about staphylococcus type.
turn_44.context: Drawing parallels between cases and seeking further details.
turn_44.source_reference: Case 9452: Dr. Cabot: That was quite like this, alung infection and then a skin infection. Was this a yellow staphylococcus ?

turn_45.speaker: Dr. Richardson
turn_45.timestamp: Post-mortem examination discussion, June 27, 1923, Confirming yellow staphylococcus
turn_45.message: Yes, presumed yellow unless noted otherwise.
turn_45.intention: Confirm the presumed type of staphylococcus.
turn_45.context: Providing standard microbiological practice in reporting.
turn_45.source_reference: Case 9452: Dr. Richardson : Yes. We presume it is yellow unless it is otherwise stated.

presentation.chief_complaint: Toxic condition, unable to give history initially; later history reveals chest pain, rapid grunting respirations, fever, arm swellings.
presentation.history_of_present_illness: 4 months of worry and emaciation. 6 days prior to admission, right lower chest pain, rapid grunting respirations. Progressed to high fever, arm swellings, confusion.
presentation.physical_exam: Slender man, rapid shallow expirations with grunt, dilated nostrils, hot perspiring skin, cyanotic lips and fingers, injected sclerae, dry coated tongue, mucoid oropharynx, reddened tonsillar fossae and pharynx, pea-to-bean sized lymph nodes, greater left chest expansion, lung signs (diagram), poor heart sounds, soft systolic apical murmur, distended hypertympanitic abdomen, slight diffuse spasm and tenderness, questionable penile scar, indurated warm tender forearm areas.

subsequent.pulse: Rapid and very poor quality (after delirium)

imaging.description: Diagram provided showing lung findings, not explicitly described in text but used to infer lung pathology.

procedures.description: For fever reduction if favorable reaction and temp ≥ 103°
Cardiac support, then t.i.d. after 3 days

procedures.procedure: Morphine gr. 1/8 with hyoscin gr. 1/200 p.r.n.

timeline_events.event: Patient started looking worried and emaciated.
Onset of right lower chest pain.
Worsening symptoms, stayed at home, rapid grunting respirations, fever, headache, thirst, malaise.
Bilateral tender swellings noticed on forearms, temperature 104°.
Admitted to Emergency Ward, toxic condition, orders placed: individual precautions, diet, fluids, chest swathe, medications.
Period of excited delirium, received Morphine and Hyoscin, pulse became rapid and poor, patient died.
Anatomical diagnosis performed by Dr. Richardson.

final_diagnoses: Dr. Richard C Cabot's Diagnosis: Pneumonia. Empyema ? Cellulitis of forearms.
